item.title: Every k Cell is Compact
item.description: Definition For $a_{i},b_{i} \in \mathbb{R} (1\le i \le k)$, the set $I=[a_{1},b_{1}] \times [a_{2},b_{2}]\times \cdots \times [a_{k},b_{k}]$ is called a $k$-cellk-cell. Here, $\times$ represents the Cartesian product of sets. Theorem 1 Let’s assume a sequence of closed intervals on $\mathbb{R}$, $\left\{ I_{n} \right\}$, satisfies $I_{n}\supset I_{n+1}\ (n=1,2,\cdots)$. Then, the following holds true. $$ \bigcap_{i=1}^{\infty}I_{n}\ne \varnothing $$ Proof Let’s denote $I_{n}=[a_{n},b_{n}]$. Also, let $E=\left\{ a_{n} : n=1,2,\cdots \right\}$. Then, $E\ne \varnothing$

item.title: Closure and Derived Set in Metric Space
item.description: Definitions Let’s say $(X,d)$ is a metric space. Suppose $p \in X$ and $E \subset X$. A set that contains all $q$ satisfying $d(q,p)<r$ is defined as the neighborhoodneighborhood of point $p$, denoted by $N_{r}(p)$. In this case, $r$ is called the radius of $N_{r}(p)$. If it’s permissible to omit the distance, it can also be denoted as $N_{p}$. If every neighborhood of $p$ includes a $q$ that is $q\ne

item.title: Neighborhood, Limit Point, Open, Closed in Metric Space
item.description: Definition Let’s say $(X,d)$ is a metric space. Suppose $p \in X$ and $E \subset X$. The set that includes all $q$s satisfying $d(q,p)<r$ is defined as the neighborhoodneighborhood of point $p$ and is denoted as $N_{r}(p)$. Here, $r$ is called the radius of $N_{r}(p)$. If the distance can be omitted, it may also be denoted as $N_{p}$. If all neighborhoods of $p$ contain $q$, which is $q\ne p$ and
